frameDefinitions: An Assessor examines a Phenomenon to figure out its Value according to some Feature of the Phenomenon.
A member or members of a Class have just been  mentioned or are present in the discourse setting and now a different instance  (or group of instances) of the same class is referred to.
The Reader attends to a Text to process its information.
A linguistic Form has a particular Meaning, possibly restricted to a particular Context.
This frame contains perception words whose perceivers intentionally direct their attention to some entity or phenomenon in order to have a perceptual experience.
This frame concerns a Cognizer (a person or other intelligent being) paying close attention to something, the Ground, in order to discover and note its salient characteristics.
frameExamples: Each company is then <t>evaluated</t> for their earning potential. CNI
My husband left me for <t>another</t> woman -- and now wants to get back together again!
I <t>read</t> A Tale of Two Cities last night.
'Unicorn' <t>denotes</t> a mythological horse with a horn on its head.
We <t>searched</t> the yard  for my contact lens.
listRoleDefinitions: The sentient entity that evaluates the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The entity whose <fen>Value</fen> according to a <fen>Feature</fen> is being measured.
The type of property or feature that the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is being judged on.
An event or procedure that allows the <fen>Assessor</fen> to evaluate the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Assessor</fen> to make the assessment.
The time at which the <fen>Assessor</fen> makes the assessment.
The location where the assessing takes place.
The general category of entity which has been referred to.
The instance of the <fen>Class</fen> that is added to the <fen>Initial_set</fen> of entities in the <fen>Class</fen>.
The previously mentioned group of entities of the <fen>Class</fen>.
The one who examines a Text to understand it.
The entity that contains linguistic symbols.
When the reading event takes place.
Where the reading event takes place.
<fen>Form</fen> is the formal pole of a linguistic sign.
<fen>Meaning</fen> is the sense of a linguistic <fen>Form</fen>.
<fen>Referent</fen> identifies an object in the real (or a hypothetical) world that a linguistic expression is used to talk about.
The <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> performs some action in order to have a perceptual experience. It is expressed as an External Argument:

<fen>Phenomenon</fen> indicates the entity or phenomenon to which the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> directs his or her attention in order to have a perceptual experience. Typically, it is expressed as an Object with verbs.
<fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the part of the body used as a sensory organ of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen>, typically expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.

<fen>Direction</fen> is used for all path-like expressions that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception, with the exception of those indicating the location of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> (which would be marked <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen>)
When the activity of attempting to perceive occurs.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> pays attention to an entity in order to discover something about it. The role is normally expressed as an External Argument:

The <fen>Cognizer</fen> pays attention to the <fen>Ground</fen>, so named because it serves as the background or context for the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>. This role can be expressed as an NP Object or as a PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the piece of text or work in which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> pays attention to an entity in order to discover something about it. The role is normally expressed as an External Argument:
An entity directed by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>  that interacts with the <fen>Ground</fen> to accomplish the scrutiny.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is scrutinizing the <fen>Ground</fen>.
listRoleExamples: You will also be graded <fex>on your speed of response</fex> .
<fex>The study</fex> evaluated the risk of a major quake.
<fex>This chapter</fex> evaluates the far-left's contribution to the environmentalism debate since the '70's .
The committee rated Smithers ' most loyal servant ' <fex>about a week ago</fex> .
They 'll evaluate you <fex>in that room over there</fex> , and then you 're free to go .
My Husband left me for another <fex>man</fex>!
A further five incursions <fex>over and above those noted for 1995</fex> took place in the first three months of 1996.
Charlie often reads the newspaper <fex>at night</fex>.
Surprisingly, few of the students read much at all <fex>in the designated reading rooms</fex>.
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled the milk to see if it was fresh.
The waiter smelled <fex>the milk</fex> to see if it was fresh.
You should feel the water <fex>with your toes</fex> before jumping in.
The detective looked <fex>across the street</fex> at the suspect.
<fex>Chapter four</fex> examined the case for free speech.
The temperature controller monitored the temperature <fex>with a calibrated silicon diode</fex>.
